challenge.description: Thermal decomposition of the material is accelerated in the presence of electrolyte.
challenge.impact: This acceleration leads to structural instability and formation of secondary phases, which can compromise the safety and performance of lithium-ion batteries.

solution.description: In situ X-ray diffraction was used to monitor thermal behavior and phase transitions under simulated real-life battery conditions.
solution.methodology: Utilization of synchrotron-based in situ XRD to study structural changes during heating in the presence of electrolyte.
solution.effectiveness: The technique provided detailed insights into the thermal degradation mechanism, enabling better understanding of the material's behavior.

evidence.source: Sections discussing thermal decomposition in the presence of electrolyte (e.g., Figures 3 and 4, and related text).
evidence.data: Observed phase transitions to rock salt and metallic phases at ~422°C and ~600°C in the presence of electrolyte.

context.material_properties: High discharge capacity (~250 mAh/g) and additional Mn4+ content contributing to thermal stability.
context.experimental_conditions: Heating from 25°C to 600°C in the presence of electrolyte.
context.application_relevance: Understanding thermal decomposition is critical for designing safer high-energy lithium-ion batteries.

challenge.description: Defect sites in the fully charged state act as nucleation sites for new phases during thermal decomposition in the presence of electrolyte.
challenge.impact: These defect sites lead to the formation of undesirable secondary phases, reducing the material's stability and performance.

solution.description: Detailed phase analysis using Pawley fitting of diffraction patterns at selected temperatures.
solution.methodology: Pawley fitting was chosen over Rietveld refinement due to the presence of imperfect crystalline phases during heating.
solution.effectiveness: The fitting successfully identified new phases such as metal carbonates and metal fluorides formed during thermal decomposition.

evidence.source: Discussion on defect sites and phase evolution in the presence of electrolyte (e.g., Figure 4 and related text).
evidence.data: Formation of metal carbonate (R-3c type hexagonal phase) and rutile-type metal fluoride phases at ~422°C and ~600°C.

context.material_properties: Contains defect sites after activation of Li2MnO3 domain.
context.experimental_conditions: Thermal testing in the presence of electrolyte at elevated temperatures.
context.application_relevance: Defect-induced phase transitions impact the material's suitability for practical battery applications.

challenge.description: Thermal instability towards electrolyte in electrochemically delithiated state.
challenge.impact: This instability leads to oxygen release and formation of secondary phases, compromising battery safety and performance.

solution.description: Study of thermal behavior using in situ XRD to understand phase transitions and structural changes.
solution.methodology: Synchrotron-based in situ XRD was employed to monitor phase evolution during heating in the presence of electrolyte.
solution.effectiveness: Provided crucial insights into the material's thermal decomposition mechanism, aiding in the design of safer batteries.

evidence.source: Sections discussing oxygen release and defect sites in the delithiated state (e.g., Figure 5 and related text).
evidence.data: Observed formation of rock salt and metallic phases at elevated temperatures in the presence of electrolyte.

context.material_properties: Electrochemically delithiated state with defect sites after activation of Li2MnO3 domain.
context.experimental_conditions: Heating in the presence of electrolyte to simulate real-life battery conditions.
context.application_relevance: Thermal instability impacts the material's safety and reliability in commercial lithium-ion batteries.
